discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ADE
A. Run MySQL Server docker containers: Docker containers are a popular way to isolate and run multiple instances of MySQL on the same host.

D. Start mysqld or mysqld_safe using different option files for each instance: You can start multiple instances of MySQL by specifying different option files for each instance, which allows you to configure them separately.

E. Run mysqld with --datadir defined for each instance: You can specify a different data directory for each MySQL instance using the --datadir option.

Selected Answer: BDE
The correct options are BDE

ABD
A ocker
B systemd and specify different config option files
D mutiple things need to be changed, so different configurations

comments.content: BTW, not E because you just specified the datadir, what about the port, the logfiles, etc.

questions.question_text:
You must run multiple instances of MySQL Server on a single host.
Which three methods are supported? (Choose three.)

choices.F: Use resource groups to lock different instances on separate CPUs.
choices.C: Use system tools to lock each instance to its own CPU.
choices.B: Use systemd with different settings for each instance.
choices.E: Run mysqld with --datadir defined for each instance.
choices.D: Start mysqld or mysqld_safe using different option files for each instance.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
"If I have already undone the changes made on the SLAVE, I only need to adjust the GTID instead of deleting all binary logs with RESET MASTER. Wouldn't it be more correct to reset the state on the SLAVE and set the GTID to 3820 on the SLAVE?

Option C."

questions.question_text:
You have configured GTID-based asynchronous replication with one master and one slave.
A user accidentally updated some data on the slave.
To fix this, you stopped replication and successfully reverted the accidental changes.
Examine the current GTID information:
//IMG//

You must fix GTID sets on the slave to avoid replicating unwanted transactions in case of failover.
Which set of actions would allow the slave to continue replicating without erroneous transactions?

choices.D: There could be both a 2 node and 3 node group replication still running, so shutting down group replication and diagnosing the issue is recommended.
choices.C: The group replication will buffer the transactions on the online nodes until the unreachable nodes return online.
choices.A: The cluster will shut down to preserve data consistency.
choices.B: The cluster has built-in high availability and updates group_replication_ip_whitelist to remove the unreachable nodes.
choices.E: A manual intervention to force group members to be only the working two instances is required.

questions.question_text:
There are five MySQL instances configured with a working group replication.
Examine the output of the group members:
//IMG//

Which two statements are true about network partitioning in the cluster? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
2 nodes online with lost quorum, therefore not processing transaction & 3 nodes online, with quorum and processing transactions

Manual intervention is REQUIRED if you need to make a group with lost quorum to process transactions.

comments.content: because there is no buffer. Binary logs are not buffer logs. When instances are back online, they will fetch from binary logs transaction, not from some buffer.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
D. There could be both a 2 node and 3 node group replication still running, so shutting down group replication and diagnosing the issue is recommended. In a situation where there is a network partition, the remaining nodes are not able to tell if the unreachable servers have crashed or whether a network partition has isolated these nodes alone and therefore the group cannot be reconfigured automatically1. This could potentially lead to both a 2 node and 3 node group replication still running.
E. A manual intervention to force group members to be only the working two instances is required. When a majority of group members is lost, the group is unable to progress and blocks because it cannot secure majority or quorum1. In this case, manual intervention may be required to reconfigure the group with only the working instances.
https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/group-replication-network-partitioning.html

D, the 3 unreachable nodes could be together in a group
E, If you want to up nodes in a cluster, you need to remove the other 3

Selected Answer: BD
Why focus on QN = 5?
It has the highest average latency (21.03 s), meaning it is the slowest-running query.
Even though it executes only once, it takes too long and could be causing a bottleneck.
Why focus on QN = 4?
It has the second-highest average latency (10.32 s), which is still significant.
It has higher execution count (200) than QN = 5, meaning it might be slowing down the system more frequently.
Why not the other options?
QN = 3: Though it has 120.24 ms lock latency, its execution time (523.32 ms) is much lower than QN = 4 and 5.
QN = 1: Has a high execution count (381,268) but low average latency (31.44 ms). This means optimizing it won’t have as much impact as fixing QN = 4 and 5.
QN = 2: Even though it has high lock latency (30.06 s), its execution time is very low (358.34 µs).
Final Answer:
✅ B. QN = 5
✅ D. QN = 4

E. high lock time -- query 2
A. Long execution time, somewhat locking. -- query 3

query 1 looks fine though there are many executions.

questions.question_text:
Examine this statement and output:
//IMG//

You must try to reduce query execution time.
Which two queries should you focus on? (Choose two.)

choices.B: total memory used by the first 10 connections
choices.F: total memory used by the first 10 threads
choices.D: total memory used across all connections associated with the user on thread number 10
choices.E: total memory used by connection number 10
choices.C: total memory used by thread number 10
choices.A: total memory used across all connections associated with the user on connection number 10
